Supported TiO2/MCM-41 as an efficient and eco-friendly catalyst for highly selective preparation of cyclohexanone oxime from solvent-free liquid phase oxidation of cyclohexylamine with molecular oxygen Shuilin Liu a c Kuiyi You a b ⁎ Jinyuan Song a Renjie Deng a Fangfang Zhao a Pingle Liu a b Qiuhong Ai a b He’an Luo a b ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan 411105, PR China School of Chemical Engineering Xiangtan University Xiangtan 411105 PR China b National & Local United Engineering Research Center for Chemical Process Simulation and Intensification, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan 411105, PR China National & Local United Engineering Research Center for Chemical Process Simulation and Intensification Xiangtan University Xiangtan 411105 PR China c School of materials and chemical engineering, Hunan Institute of Technology, Hengyang 421002, PR China School of materials and chemical engineering Hunan Institute of Technology Hengyang 421002 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: College of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan, 411105. PR China. College of Chemical Engineering Xiangtan University Xiangtan 411105 PR China Graphical abstract A green and efficient approach for solvent-free selective catalytic oxidation of cyclohexylamine to cyclohexanone oxime in liquid phase has been developed. The results showed that the supported 30%TiO2/MCM-41 as efficient and eco-friendly catalyst gave 78.4% of cyclohexylamine conversion with 89.1% of selectivity to cyclohexanone oxime. It has been demonstrated that the catalytic active sites are the surface titanium hydroxyl groups of catalyst. Moreover, the present catalyst can be easily separated, recycled, regenerated and reused. The probable catalytic reaction mechanism of cyclohexylamine with molecular oxygen over supported TiO2/MCM-41 was suggested. This work affords a new and environmentally friendly route for the synthesis of cyclohexanone oxime, and has important industrial application prospects. Keywords Supported TiO2/MCM-41 Cyclohexylamine Cyclohexanone oxime Molecular oxygen Solvent-free Liquid phase catalytic oxidation 1 Introduction Cyclohexanone oxime (abbreviated to CHO) is a crucial organic intermediate for the synthesis of ε-caprolactam, which is widely used in synthetic fibers and resins [1]. Nowadays, the synthesis routes of CHO mainly involve “cyclohexanone-hydroxylamine” method [2], ammoximation of cyclohexanone [3,4], nitrosation of cyclohexane [5–7], one-step hydrogenation of nitrocyclohexane [8,9] and partial oxidation of cyclohexylamine (Scheme 1 ). However, there are more or less problems in above-mentioned these processes, for example, cyclohexanone suffers from the low efficiency oxidation of cyclohexane (the conversion must be controlled at below 5%) [10,11], nitrosyl chloride (NOCl) is very corrosive, troublesome and environmentally unamiable, and nitrocyclohexane is not easy to be obtained. Recently, Rubio-Marqués reported a new synthesis method of CHO by employing nitrobenzene and hydroxylamine hydrochloride as raw materials, and Au/C-Pd/C as catalysts in the presence of hydrogen [12]. However, this process used hydroxylamine salts as reactant and noble metals as catalysts. Therefore, there is very urgent to develop a highly efficient, economical and green method for the preparation of CHO. Generally, cyclohexylamine can be obtained from the hydrogenation of aniline, ammonification of cyclohexene with ammonia or ammonolysis of cyclohexanol with ammonia [13]. From the points of view of the source of starting materials and cost of oxidants, directly converting of cyclohexylamine to CHO by oxidation method is regarded as a promising alternative route [14]. In recent years, for the selective oxidation of cyclohexylamine to CHO, the oxidants were focused on the hydrogen peroxide, alkyl hydroperoxides and molecular oxygen [15]. Although hydrogen peroxide and alkyl hydroperoxides (such as tert-butyl or cumyl hydroperoxide) used as oxidizers can efficiently convert amines to oximes [16–18], the cost, safety and the separation of their organic reduction byproducts from the reaction system should be cautiously considered. Therefore, it is highly eager to develop a more economic, safe, efficient and environmentally benign process for the selective oxidation of amines to oximes by employing dioxygen as a green oxidant. Rakottyay [19,20] and Kaszonyi [21] reported the vapor phase catalytic oxidation of cyclohexylamine with molecular oxygen over modified WO3/Al2O3, and the selectivity to CHO was only close to 70% with about 20% of cyclohexylamine conversion. Klitgaard and co-workers [22] investigated the liquid-phase oxidation of cyclohexylamine with oxygen by employing titania as catalyst in the presence of solvent n-decane, and 16% of amine conversion with 70% of selectivity to CHO was obtained. Suzuki et al [23,24] reported the selective oxidation of amine in the liquid-phase process employing DPPH and WO3/Al2O3 as composite catalysts and acetonitrile as solvent, and the excellent yield to target oxime was obtained. Yu et al reported the composite catalytic system 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl(TEMPO)/acetaldoxime/InCl3 and 3-Methyl-4-oxa-5-azahomoadamantane/acetaldoxime could efficiently catalyze the oxidation of amines to corresponding oximes [25,26]. However, these methods refer to use organic solvents or expensive and complex catalysts, which maybe limit their application in the industry field. Therefore, there is much desired to develop a more simple, highly efficient and benign approach for highly selective preparation of CHO under solvent-free condition. Recently, some research works have showed the mesoporous SBA-15 [27] and silica gel [28] with rich surface hydroxyl groups exhibit excellent catalytic performance in the gas-phase oxidation of cyclohexylamine with oxygen to CHO. Furthermore, titania-based catalysts have been also widely used in some oxidation reactions for the synthesis of important organic chemical intermediates. Zhou et al [29] reported Ti-MWW catalyst could efficiently catalyze liquid-phase selective oxidation of cyclohexane to KA oil. Immobilized Ti-MCM-41 catalysts were proved to be efficient for several oxidation reactions, such as the epoxidation of cyclohexene [30,31], stilbene [32], unsaturated alcohols [33] and vegetable oils [34], and the selective oxidation of organic sulfides [35] and ethyl benzene [36]. Herein, we present a mild and green method for the solvent-free selective oxidation of cyclohexylamine with dioxygen to CHO in liquid phase by employing supported TiO2/MCM-41 as an efficient and stable catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and instrument MCM-41, Hβ, γ-Al2O3 and silica gel were purchased from Nanjing Micron-nanometer materials Technology Co., Ltd. Cyclohexylamine, tetrabutyl titanate and other chemical reagents were analytical grade, and were purchased commercially. The quantitative and qualitative analysis of reaction products were performed on Agilent 7890B GC and GCMS-QP2010Plus (Shimadzu, Japan), respectively. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The supported catalysts were prepared by sol-gel method. Typically, the supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts were obtained according to the following steps. Firstly, tetrabutyl titanate was added to a mixture of ethanol and MCM-41 under stirring. The mass ratio of TiO2 to MCM-41 was in the range of 0.11–1. Meanwhile, a certain amount of acetic acid and nitric acid as hydrolysis inhibitor was added to this mixture. Then, the aqueous solution of ethanol was dropwise added to the above mixed solution at room temperature. The resulted sol solution was evaporated at 35 °C for 48 h, and the obtained gel was dried at 80 °C for 10 h. At last, the resulted solids were calcined in muffle furnace at 500 °C for 4 h in air. 2.3 Characterization of catalyst The textural properties were recorded by N2 physisorption at 77 K on a Quantachrome NOVA-2200e. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was adopted to figure the specific surface areas, and the pore sizes and the pore volumes of samples were calculated according to the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Surface hydroxyl groups of samples were determined on a Nicoletis vacuum infrared characterization system using KBr pellets and the sample degassing was carried out at 373 K and 10−5 Pa for 2 h. The Rigaku D/Max-2550V+ diffractometer employing Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at 40 kV and 300 mA was used for recording the XRD patterns of the samples. The HRTEM images of samples were obtained on a JEM-2100 with a lattice resolution of 0.19 nm and an accelerating voltage of 200 kV, and SEM images were obtained on a JSM-6610LV spectrometer. The XPS analysis of the samples was performed in a ESCALAB 250Xi analyzer with Al Kα radiation at 160 eV pass energy, and the binding energies of elements were calibrated according to the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV. 2.4 Typical experimental procedures The liquid phase oxidation reaction of cyclohexylamine and molecular oxygen over catalyst was performed in stainless steel reactor. Firstly, a certain amount of cyclohexylamine and catalyst were added into reactor, and then heating the reactor. When the reaction temperature reached to 373 K, O2 was introduced into the reaction autoclave. The catalytic oxidation reaction was performed at constant oxygen pressure for 4 h with stirring. After the reaction, the quantification of oxidation products was performed on GC with FID detector (toluene as internal standard sample). All products were identified by GC–MS. The conversion of cyclohexylamine and the selectivity to CHO, cyclohexanone (CH), nitrocyclohexane (NCH) and cyclohexyl-cyclohexylidene-amine (CCA) were calculated according to the following formulas, respectively. (1) C o n v e r s i o n o f c y c l o h e x y l a m i n e = t h e m o l e o f c y c l o h e x y l a m i n e r e a c t e d t h e m o l e o f c y c l o h e x y l a m i n e a d d e d × 100 % (2) S e l e c t i v i t y o f C H O ( % ) = t h e m o l e o f C H O t h e m o l e o f c y c l o h e x y l a m i n e r e a c t e d × 100 % (3) S e l e c t i v i t y o f N C H ( % ) = t h e m o l e o f N C H t h e m o l e o f c y c l o h e x y l a m i n e r e a c t e d × 100 % (4) S e l e c t i v i t y o f C H ( % ) = t h e m o l e o f C H t h e m o l e o f c y c l o h e x y l a m i n e r e a c t e d × 100 % (5) S e l e c t i v i t y o f C C A ( % ) = 2 × t h e m o l e o f C C A t h e m o l e o f c y c l o h e x y l a m i n e r e a c t e d × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The catalytic performance of various catalysts in the liquid phase oxidation reaction In order to seek the efficient catalyst for selective converting of cyclohexylamine to CHO, some typical oxidation catalysts were screened. For example, N-Hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) is well known in the oxidation of ethylbenzene to acetophenone [37,38]. Phosphotungstic acid (HPW) is usually employed in the selective oxidation of alcohols and diesel oil [39,40]. In addition, γ-Al2O3 is also used in the oxidation of volatile organic compounds [41]. Table 1 summarized the catalytic performances of various catalysts in present oxidation under the set reaction conditions. In fact, CHO could be obtained in the absence of any catalysts, but the cyclohexylamine conversion was only 9.3% with 24.0% of selectivity to CHO. However, the oxidation catalysts (silica gel, MCM-41, Hβ, NHPI and HPW) were introduced to this oxidation reaction, both the conversion and selectivity were improved in different degrees, and HPW gave the higher conversion (34.4%) and selectivity to CHO (64.7%). Furthermore, we employed some metal oxides, such as ZrO2, γ-Al2O3 and TiO2 to catalyze this oxidation reaction. To our delight, TiO2 exhibited excellent catalytic performance, and 68.7% of cyclohexylamine conversion with 84.8% of selectivity to CHO were obtained. In order to further enhance the catalytic performance of TiO2, we attempted to prepare supported TiO2 by incorporating the carriers during in situ synthesis of titania (such as TiO2/γ-Al2O3, TiO2/Hβ, TiO2/Silica gel and TiO2/MCM-41). The results showed the supported 30%TiO2/MCM-41 further boosted the feed stock conversion and target product selectivity, and 78.4% of cyclohexylamine conversion with 89.1% of selectivity to CHO was achieved under the set reaction conditions. 3.2 Effects of TiO2 loading on the catalytic performance Table 2 summarizes the effects of TiO2 loading on the conversion and CHO selectivity. Obviously, compared to the bulk TiO2 catalyst, the cyclohexylamine conversion and CHO selectivity were remarkably improved over supported TiO2/MCM-41 under the equal mass of TiO2 condition. This could be explained by highly dispersed titania particles on MCM-41 contributing to complete exposure of active sites. However, further enhancing the loading of active component TiO2 to 50% resulted in a decreasing trend of the conversion and selectivity to CHO. The possible reason was that too much titania would be agglomerated on the carrier, thus, the catalytic active sites of catalyst failed to be full exposed. Among these supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts, 30%TiO2/MCM-41 catalyst gave the best results with 78.4% of cyclohexylamine conversion and 89.1% of selectivity to CHO. 3.3 Optimization of reaction conditions Fig. 1 depicted the effects of reaction temperature, oxygen pressure, reaction time and the amount of catalyst on the catalytic oxidation reaction over 30%TiO2/MCM-41. The results demonstrated that the cyclohexylamine conversion increased gradually, while the selectivity to CHO first increased and then decreased with elevated reaction parameters. Meanwhile, the selectivity to NCH and CH increased slowly, and the selectivity to CCA showed the decline trend. In this oxidation process, the products distribution may be affected by the mass transfer limitations. Mass transfer limitations include both the internal and external diffusion of components into and out of the catalyst. In the present heterogeneous catalytic system, efficient utilization of 30% TiO2/MCM-41 catalyst surface depends on the mass transfer limitations inside the pore structure. The transfer of oxygen from the gas phase to the cyclohexylamine phase proceeds at a high rate. Simultaneously, a portion of oxygen and cyclohexylamine are transported fast to outer surface of catalyst, then enter the inner pores of the catalyst, and are reacted on the inner surface to form oxidation products. The reactants are consumed and products are formed, which bring the concentration differences between reactants and products. The concentration gradient is the driving force for mass transfer and a vital factor determining the mass transfer flux. Cyclohexylamine is converted rapidly into the reaction products over catalyst due to the concentration gradient of cyclohexylamine and oxidation products. However, the concentration gradient of cyclohexylamine decreases with prolonged reaction time, which results in a decrease in mass transfer flux. Thus, the cyclohexylamine conversion becomes slower (as shown in Fig.1C). In addition, the selectivity to by-products such as nitrocyclohexane becomes larger and the selectivity to CCA shows the obvious decrease trend due to the increase of the residence time of the reaction intermediate inside the catalyst. Therefore, the appropriate reaction temperature is 100 °C, the oxygen pressure is 1 MPa, the reaction time is 4 h and the amount of catalyst is 0.3 g. It is worth mentioning that, from these above factors, it can be seen that CCA is seemed to be an intermediate, which can be converted into CH and CHO. In order to verify whether CCA can be oxidized to CHO and CH, we further investigated the oxidation reaction of CCA with dioxygen, and the obtained results were shown in Table 3 . It turned out that CCA was quickly converted to CH and CHO in the absence of additive. Unfortunately, the selectivity to CHO was only 38.2%. However, the selectivity to CHO increased rapidly with elevated amount of additive, 91.9% of selectivity to CHO and 98.7% of CCA conversion were achieved as the amount of additive was increased to 3.0 g. This indicated that CCA could be oxidized efficiently to CHO in the presence of additive oxime. On the basis of above-obtained results, a schematic reaction network for cyclohexylamine and molecular oxygen is depicted in Scheme 2 . Cyclohexylamine can be directly oxidized to CHO as main reaction. Meanwhile, cyclohexylamine can also be oxidized to NCH and CH as side reaction. In the presence of cyclohexylamine, CH can be converted into CCA [9,42], and CCA can be oxidized to CHO and CH again. 3.4 Catalyst characterization The physic-chemical properties of supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts are characterized by BET, XRD, SEM, TEM and XPS. Fig. 2 shows the adsorption-desorption isotherms of nitrogen and pore size distribution. Clearly, there is a type H1 hysteresis loop in the isotherms of MCM-41, 10%TiO2/MCM-41 and 30%TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts, which indicates that the catalysts possess the mesoporous structure [43]. However, for the 50%TiO2/MCM-41 catalyst, the hysteresis loop almost disappears. The probable reason is that the partial pores of MCM-41 are filled by overmuch TiO2 particles, resulting in the decline of the specific surface areas and pore volume. Also, it is clearly seen that pore diameters of supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts belong to mesoporous scope from the desorption isotherm in Fig. 2 B. Furthermore, Table 4 summarizes the BET characterization results of several samples. Obviously, the effects of TiO2 loading on the specific surface area and pore volume are remarkable, which decrease with increased TiO2 loading. It is worth mentioning that, the textural parameters of used sample are still be restored as a fresh sample after calcining at 550 °C for 4 h in air, which demonstrates the supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts can be regenerated. Fig. 3 depicts the XRD patterns for the small-angle and wide-angle of MCM-41 and supported TiO2/MCM-41 samples. Obviously, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 2.41°, 4.03° and 4.63°, which belong to the characteristic peaks of highly ordered mesostructured MCM-41 [44], are still observed in the supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts in Fig. 3 A. This reveals the characteristic mesoporous structure of MCM-41 is not destroyed by TiO2 particles. Fig. 3 B shows the wide-angle XRD patterns of samples. The diffraction peaks of anatase TiO2 are hardly observed in the supported 10%TiO2/MCM-41 sample, which indicates the TiO2 particles exhibit high dispersity on the surface of MCM-41 [45,46]. However, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 25.3°, 37.8°, 48°, 55°, 62.8°, 70.4°, 75.1° and 82.9°, which are attributed to the characteristic peaks of anatase TiO2 (JCPDS: 84-1286) [47], are evidently observed in the supported 30%TiO2/MCM-41 and 50%TiO2/MCM-41 samples. These results indicate that the TiO2 particles supported on the MCM-41 are anatase. Fig. 4 shows the SEM images of MCM-41 and supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts. As can be seen, the micrograph of pure MCM-41 show large petal shaped spherical particles. For the low TiO2 loading (≤30%) catalysts, spherical particles can still be clearly observed, while the surface of supported catalysts become rough, which shows that the TiO2 particles are well dispersed on the carrier. However, local accumulation of excess TiO2 particles results in breaking petal shaped spherical morphology as the loading of TiO2 is increased to 50%. Therefore, the loading of catalyst is a very important factor to maintain the morphology. Fig. 5 shows the TEM images of MCM-41 and supported TiO2/MCM-41 samples. For the low TiO2 loading catalysts (≤30%), it is easy to observe the ordered hexagonal channels, which indicates the TiO2 particles exhibit high dispersity on the surface of MCM-41. However, for the high TiO2 loading catalysts (≥50%), it can be clearly observed that the plentiful TiO2 particles are aggregated together and formed local accumulation. Furthermore, lattice fringes of TiO2 particles can be observed obviously from the HRTEM image of supported 30%TiO2/MCM-41 catalyst (Fig. 5c). The average fringes spacing of about 0.235 nm and 0.351 nm are assigned to (001) and (101) lattice plane of anatase titania, respectively [48]. The XPS spectra of MCM-41 and supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts are depicted in Fig. 6 . From the XPS survey spectra, it can be seen that the Si, Ti, and O three elements present in the supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts. Fig. 6 b shows the Si 2p at binding energy 103.5 eV XPS spectra of MCM-41 and supported catalysts. It can be observed that the intensity of Si 2p peak decreases with increasing TiO2 loading. From the Fig. 6c, only one peak at binding energy 532.6 eV, which is assigned to surface silicon hydroxyl (Si−OH), presents in the O 1s spectra of MCM-41. However, there are two peaks at binding energy 532.6 eV and 530.3 eV in the O 1s spectra of supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts, which are assigned to surface silicon hydroxyl (Si−OH) and titanium hydroxyl (Ti−OH) [49], respectively. Moreover, for the supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts, there are two peaks at binding energy 464.5 ± 0.2 and 458.8 ± 0.2 eV in the XPS spectra of Ti 2p (Fig. 6d), which belong to Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 peaks, respectively, and the difference value of binding energy is 5.7 eV, which are ascribed to the Ti4+ oxidation state [50,51]. 3.5 The recycle of supported 30%TiO2/MCM-41catalyst in the oxidation reaction The stability of supported 30%TiO2/MCM-41 catalyst was investigated in the oxidation of cyclohexyamine and molecular oxygen. The used catalyst was disposed by filtration, washing with ethanol, drying at 80 °C and calcining at 550 °C for 4 h. The results showed that 30%TiO2/MCM-41 catalyst exhibited excellent stability in the liquid phase oxidation reaction, and 78% of cyclohexylamine conversion with 89% of selectivity to CHO was still achieved after five runs. Moreover, in order to further confirm the stability of 30%TiO2/MCM-41 catalyst in the reaction process, the sample after recycling five times was characterized by small-angle and wide-angle XRD, as shown in Fig. 7 . Obviously, compared to fresh catalyst, the small-angle and wide-angle diffraction peaks of used catalyst were hardly changed, which indicated that the highly ordered mesoporous structure and crystalline shape of catalyst were still maintained in the recycle process. 3.6 The possible catalytic reaction mechanism of cyclohexylamine with molecular oxygen over supported TiO2/MCM-41 According to the obtained results in this work and our previous work [28], we proposed a possible reaction mechanism and formation pathway of oxidation products, as shown in Fig. 8 . Initially, cyclohexylamine is easy to be adsorbed on the catalyst surface by the intermolecular hydrogen bonding between titanium hydroxyl groups and amine groups. Subsequently, the adsorbed-activated amine is dehydrated to a transient species, which is quickly oxidized to hydroperoxide adduct by molecular oxygen (Fig. 8a). Finally, the hydroperoxide intermediate was released from the adduct in the presence of water. The resulting hydroperoxide intermediate can be decomposed rapidly to nitroso-cyclohexane by intramolecular dehydration, which is very easy to be rearranged to CHO. Meanwhile, nitroso-cyclohexane can also be oxidized to NCH. Furthermore, we suggested the schematic pathway for catalytic oxidation of amines with molecular oxygen (Fig. 8b). The adsorbed-activated cyclohexylamine can be oxidized to two hydroperoxide intermediates on the NH and α-CH site [52], respectively. The formed hydroperoxide intermediate on the NH site as main reaction is favorable to forming CHO. However, the formed hydroperoxide intermediate on the α-CH site as side reaction may be converted to CH and hydroxylamine [21]. It is worth mentioning that the CH can be rapidly converted into CCA in the presence of cyclohexylamine, and CCA can also be partly oxidized into CHO and CH in present reaction system. This is also confirmed by our experiments. Therefore, the surface titanium hydroxyl groups of catalyst play a significant role on initiating the NH site oxidation of cyclohexylamine. In order to further identify the surface titanium hydroxyl groups (Ti−OH) as catalytic active sites in the supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalyst, the 30%TiO2/MCM-41 was calcined at different temperature, and the catalytic activity of obtained catalyst was examined, as shown in Fig. 9 . The results indicated the catalytic activity of catalyst decreased remarkably with increasing calcination temperature. The possible reason was the reduction of surface hydroxyl groups of catalyst under the higher calcination temperature. In order to further confirm the change of surface hydroxyl groups of catalyst, 30%TiO2/MCM-41 catalysts obtained at different calcination temperature were characterized by Nicoletis vacuum infrared system, and the results were presented in Fig. 10 . Obviously, the intensity of peaks at 1630 cm−1 and 3380 cm−1 attributed to the stretching vibration of acidic titanium hydroxyl with hydrogen-bonding interactions evidently weakened with increasing calcination temperature, which indicated that the surface hydroxyl groups were decreased. 4 Conclusions In summary, a green and efficient approach for the solvent-free selective oxidation of cyclohexylamine to CHO in liquid phase has been developed. The results demonstrate that the catalytic active sites are surface titanium hydroxyl groups of catalyst, which play crucial roles on the activation of cyclohexylamine. Under optimum reaction conditions, the supported 30%TiO2/MCM-41 catalyst as efficient and environmentally friendly catalyst gives 78.4% of cyclohexylamine conversion with 89.1% of selectivity to CHO. Moreover, the developed catalyst can be easily separated, recycled, regenerated and reused. Finally, the possible catalytic reaction mechanism and formation pathways of products over supported TiO2/MCM-41 catalyst were also suggested. Maybe this method affords a green and environmentally benign route for the synthesis of CHO and has important industrial application prospects. coredata.dc:description: A green and efficient approach for solvent-free selective catalytic oxidation of cyclohexylamine to cyclohexanone oxime in liquid phase has been developed. The results showed that the supported 30%TiO2/MCM-41 as efficient and eco-friendly catalyst gave 78.4% of cyclohexylamine conversion with 89.1% of selectivity to cyclohexanone oxime. It has been demonstrated that the catalytic active sites are the surface titanium hydroxyl groups of catalyst. Moreover, the present catalyst can be easily separated, recycled, regenerated and reused. The probable catalytic reaction mechanism of cyclohexylamine with molecular oxygen over supported TiO2/MCM-41 was suggested. This work affords a new and environmentally friendly route for the synthesis of cyclohexanone oxime, and has important industrial application prospects.
coredata.dc:title: Supported TiO2/MCM-41 as an efficient and eco-friendly catalyst for highly selective preparation of cyclohexanone oxime from solvent-free liquid phase oxidation of cyclohexylamine with molecular oxygen
